column1: Will the UN declare that a famine exists in any part of Afghanistan in 2022?
column6: ['Society', 'Health', 'Security and Conflict']
I should have updated this to 0% earlier.
Passage of time
This is perhaps 1% per week.
Time decay - the bar on declaring famine is really high - that doesn't mean the situation isn't severe.

There have been just two famines in the 21st century. In 2011, amid a severe drought and conflict, famine was declared in Somalia after an estimated 250,000 people died. In 2017, after years of civil war, parts of South Sudan were found to be experiencing famine.
The UN warning that Afghanistan is on the brink of famine, oddly, makes me more confident they aren't going to declare the famine in the next month.
Weather is expected to be warmer and drier this winter than normal, which should make food supplies more reliable and calorie intakes lower.
before Christmas because Iran prefers dealing with Russia

Looks like Afghanistan is at very high risk, however the lean season over winter is needed to advance from where things are, so while I think famine is likely to be declared at some point, the threshold has to be high and another winter is needed to tip widely from level 4 to level 5. Hence I don’t think this will resolve yes by end 2022. Maybe early 2023 though.
Time decay and no sign of being closer to official Famine declaration, statements continue to say 'at risk of famine' but actions are taken.
My forecast has been at 30% or 35% since I started this question. I'm lowering my forecast now because little has fundamentally changed, and 2022 is almost over.
Taliban secures grain
I’m far from the median but not seeing a “famine” declaration in the cards just yet. A couple of news articles singling out Somalia, however:
At the end of August, the UN says 6 million Afghans were at risk of famine, 1 million children are suffering from life-threatening malnutrition. as crises grow.

State 5 of the fewsn has to be reached in order for famine to be declared. Last statuses reported:June 2021, parts of the country state 3 (crisis) out of 5 (famine) by famine early warnings systems network.
The threshold for declaring a famine is too high. UN is concentraiting on the Horn of Africa.

The Biden admin said today they will be transferring $3.5 billion to Afghanistan to help with efforts amid widespread hunger. The funds, half of the $7 billion Afghan government funds left in NY banks by previous government and frozen when Taliban took power, will be dispersed by the trustees of the new Afghan Fund (conformed by two Afghan economists, a US gov representative and a Swiss gov representative). If distributed timely, this can help alleviate immediate needs in the most affected areas.
Dropping further. We will know more when this analysis is made public, but I’d expect other areas that have long been in crisis to be the more likely candidates for a famine declaration.

https://fews.net/central-asia/afghanistanFEWS early warning service medium projection from July 2022 to January 2023 do not expect it to reach higher that IPC Phase 3 (and in fact will decline to Phase 2 in the highlands following the harvest), whereas Phase 5 is the threshold required for famine declaration."Current and upcoming harvesting of wheat, potatoes, fruits, and other crops—along with some income from the sale of livestock and livestock products—is expected to continue providing rural households with food and income, with the number of people facing Crisis (IPC Phase 3) outcomes expected to continue declining as harvesting progresses before the onset of the winter. Around August, harvesting in higher elevation areas is expected to improve outcomes to Stressed (IPC Phase 2). However, very poor macroeconomic conditions, reduced access to typical sources of income (including from labor and remittances from Iran), and above-average prices will continue to drive Crisis (IPC Phase 3) outcomes for worst-affected market-dependent households in both rural and urban areas. In rural areas worst-affected by poor crop and livestock production, area-level Crisis (IPC Phase 3) outcomes are likely to re-emerge by January 2023."
Updating probability - shorter timeframe vs last time I forecast = lower probability; also reflecting comments on other forecasts on condition slightly improving

The current forecast to the end of the year is showing a very slight improvement in the situation. Things might be bad now, but if that means it isn’t already a famine things need to get worse which is against the forecast, so I’m reduce the odds. The threshold for declaring a famine seems quite high.

Reverting to my original thinking that it’s more likely than not that formal famine conditions won’t be met—or announced—this year. Summer-fall should be relatively manageable. I am a lot more pessimistic for the winter-spring, both due to the natural constraints of the season and the ongoing war in Ukraine. It does not appear Russia negotiated the grain deal in good faith.
Reaffirming forecast

I set out the famine stage conditions to be met in my first forecast here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1396815WHO have now issued their latest projection here, naming a community of 20,000 people in Ghot which may meet the 5/5 threshold: https://www.wfp.org/publications/hunger-hotspots-fao-wfp-early-warnings-acute-food-insecurity-june-september-2022Contributing factors it lists are below-average harvests (p8), humanitarian access constraints (although these are improving - p11), However, the relative projections on page 12-13 indicate that they do not expect any large number (measured in millions) of Afghanistan's people to reach the necessary stage 5. 12.9 million are projected for stage 3, and 6 million are projected for stage 4.Page 20 is worth reading, as is this summary: "In Afghanistan, acute food insecurity is expected to remain at extremely high levels in the outlook period. For the first time since the introduction of IPC in Afghanistan, Catastrophic conditions (IPC Phase 5) are present for 20 000 people in Ghor due to limited humanitarian access during the March to May period. Overall, 18.9 million are projected to face Crisis or worse (IPC Phase 3 or above) between June and November – 6 million of them in Emergency (IPC Phase 4).39 In the outlook period, food insecurity numbers are projected to increase by almost 60 percent compared to the same period last year, and although the cereal harvest season is approaching, acute food insecurity is projected to reduce only slightly.

End of the lean season, beginning of harvest season. The situation probably won't get better, but likely won't get worse either.

Being landlocked and mountainous, remote provices of Afghanistan are very difficult to reach by international aid organizations and transport & logistics to get there is long, intricate, costly and dangerous. Taliban government's co-operation is vital however not always trusted. On top of that, grain prices have not significantly eased since March and the outlook is devastating.

The Ukraine war will likely cause famine this fall in areas in Africa and the Middle East. At risk areas like Yemen and Afghanistan will be especially hard hit. Ukraine is a large exporter of grain and fertilizer. Many places throughout the world are not planting or are fertilizing less.
India bans wheat exports.

From their 9th May report, even in their worst-case scenario, the two most-at-risk provinces (Ghor and Badakshan) the IPC predicted that: "the team concluded that there is not a Risk of Famine [in Ghor] during the projection period... In [Badakshan] the worst case scenario there will be no Risk of Famine. The population classified in IPC Phase 5 (Catastrophe) will increase sharply to 10-15%, but will not cross 20%. Mortality is unlikely to reach famine levels in this short time span. Unlike in Ghor, the situation in Badakshan is borderline and will require close monitoring."
For now, less so, but further assessments should be made in a few weeks:

There have been two more famines in Afghanistan since recorded history in the area (according to wikipedia): 1971 and 1998, which came due to droughts and at 27 years intervals, which could coincide with 2025 (close enough). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_famines

the Afghani climate is rather unforgiving and we are entering spring. Afghanistan depends greatly on food imports for feeding their population, which with the recent regime change (Talibans) may leave commercial links weakened and credit capacity or purchases limited.

I do still think (perhaps I just hope) that food aid from external funders + unfrozen Afghan funds (of which some might, hopefully, be spent on food distribution) reduce the chance that the very strict conditions necessary for a UN "famine" declaration will materialise.

From 2011: "While many countries worldwide face food security crises, with large numbers of people hungry and unable to find enough food, only rarely do the conditions meet the humanitarian community’s formal criteria for a famine. The last time it was used in Somalia, for example, was in 1991-92, despite several periods of protracted drought and other problems in the intervening years. [...] According to WFP, famines have been declared previously in southern areas of Sudan in 2008; in Gode in the Somali region of Ethiopia in 2000; in the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea (DPRK) in 1996; in Somalia in 1991-1992, and Ethiopia in 1984-1985." https://news.un.org/en/story/2011/07/382342-when-food-security-crisis-becomes-famine
The threshold for how famines are officially declared is available here: https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/02/23/516642447/who-declares-a-famine-and-what-does-that-actually-mean
It's already in famine.

The Biden administration's recent moves to release cash for Afghanistan make a famine significantly more remote. As covered in a previous update, the bar is very high for the UN to declare a famine, and it is rarely met. Other more precarious situations in Africa and Yemen are not currently being declared famines. Reduced likelihood of famine declaration therefore.

Afghanistan lacks an effective government and will not take the necessary actions to avoid famine.
Failure of the government in Afganistan

- Prior is high likelihood based on media coverage; however, Afghanistan is currently classified as between 2 and 3 on the Famine Early Warning Site - would be good to know how often countries progress from 2 to 3. Put initial probability at 60%. - Insufficient food consumption is >40% on World Hunger Map across all regions has been trending downwards but recently ticked back up. Adjust probability down to 45%. - Politically there is an incentive to declare Afghanistan in famine if UN wants more resources directed there; however international attention currently directed on Afghanistan may prevent the country from moving to Phase 5. Adjust probability down to 35%.

As other users have pointed out, it's made clear in the UN documentation [ https://news.un.org/en/story/2011/07/382342-when-food-security-crisis-becomes-famine ] "The declaration of a famine carries no binding obligations on the UN or member states, but serves to focus global attention on the problem."

March: UN Secretary General lists Afghanistan as one of the countries on brink of famine. UN establishes task force (https://www.un.org/press/en/2021/sgsm20619.doc.htm) June 2021: Afghanistan identified as a food insecurity hot spot by WFP and FAO (https://docs.wfp.org/api/documents/WFP-0000125170/download/?_ga=2.268916725.547868199.1616512658-940508497.1602276079) November 2021: "Afghanistan is becoming the world’s largest humanitarian crisis, with the country's needs surpassing those of the other worst-hit countries — Ethiopia, South Sudan, Syria and even Yemen." (https://www.wfp.org/stories/42-million-people-are-knocking-famines-door-and-us66-billion-could-save-them-now-0)
Afghanistan described as “vulnerable,” but not one of the four hot spots listed here: https://www.wfpusa.org/articles/hunger-hotspots-four-countries-face-famine-un-report-warns/

Famine has been a constant reality in Afghanistan, whether officially declared or not. With the rise of the Taliban, government disfunction makes famine much more possible. However, it is also a possibility that the Taliban will block UN efforts to determine ground truth in the country, leading to only a 65% probability.

https://www.ipcinfo.org/ipc-country-analysis/details-map/en/c/1155210/?iso3=AFG https://www.wfp.org/stories/our-presence-hope-us26bn-needed-winter-spells-hunger-afghanistan https://www.wfp.org/countries/afghanistan https://news.un.org/en/tags/famine

The qualifications needed for the UN to declare a stage 5 famine include three aspects that must all be met; one in five households now faces an extreme lack of food, more than 30 percent of the population is suffering from acute malnutrition, and at least two people out of every 10,000 are dying each day. It seems those conditions haven't been met yet. Erring on the lower side given the three conditions, bureaucratic process of measuring them and actually making the declaration.

Why hasn't the UN declared a famine already? The UN's definition of a famine: 20% or more families face extreme shortage (met: more than half of families are expected to face potentially life-threatening food insecurity this winter, according to the New York Times) 30% or more of children suffer from acute malnutrition (met?: if 41% of children are stunted, aren't they also suffering from acute malnutrition) 41% of children are stunted (met: 41% of children under 5 are stunted according to UNICEF) Daily death rate exceeds 2/10,000 (mortality is difficult to know)

There would probably need to be sustained civil unrest in a particular region to meet the criteria for a famine. The solidity of Taliban control plus the support of China and food aid make this prospect seem unlikely, especially with various other vested interests paying close attention to the post-US-withdrawal status of the country.

Accessibility constraints. (Conflict-driven) internal displacement. Liquidity crisis (financial crisis, currency crisis, sanctions, frozen central bank assets). Dependency on wheat grain as food staple, price development (inflation). Winter. Drought. Risk for additional natural disaster, vulnerability to multiple shocks.

I started with a base case of 50%. I looked through FEWSNET's analysis of food security in Afghanistan which was updated in October 2021, and which therefore took into account the increase in displaced people in September 2021. FEWSNET had classified about 3/4 of Afghan counties as Level 3 (food crisis) and 1/4 at Level 4 (food emergency.) It isn't inevitable that counties in Level 4 will degrade to famine (Level 5) but it seemed to me at least as likely as not that at least some will: given that the Level 4 classification means that families are taking drastic steps e.g. eating up the cereals they would normally stock for the lean season (Jan-May according to FEWSNET.) I've reduced the risk from this base case because (a) large ($1bn +) humanitarian aid pledges from the EU and other countries since October 2021 should keep food aid flowing into Afghanistan, and (b) recent talks in Oslo where it was agreed that the Taliban will gain some access to $280m of Afghanistan's frozen reserve funding, of which some might be spent on food imports.

World Food Program: "A total 45 million people are on the brink of famine across 43 countries (as of Nov. 2021) and the slightest shock will push them over the edge, the World Food Programme (WFP) warned today (8 Nov). This number has risen from 42 million earlier in the year and 27 million in 2019. Food insecurity is increasing around the world post-pandemic as high inflation rises." Afghanistan figures among the top 10 countries in terms of food insecurity and starvation, it is in fact the second country in the world with the most severe food insecurity situation, second after Congo and followed by Yemen.

The lack of accurate data / info to the UN will be a hinderance to real time knowledge of Famine conditions. My guess is that if happening in Afghanistan during 2022 it would still not be recognized until after 2022 is over.
The country is already suffering from food shortages in many provinces. After the winter, the situation seems to be worsen in Kandahar and Herat area.
The already dire situation makes it in any reasonable way a famine already. But UN rationale for such declaration is unclear to me.
Increasing reports of poverty and starvation, crop failures reported.
Seems to have been 8 famines since 1990s, mainly associated with war. Afghanistan seems to have a widespread crisis but probably not heading to famine. Will need to watch for updates.
Based on western news reports.
The fragile infrastructure they were trying to rebuild is destroyed, and the Taliban seems more interested in punishing enemies than in rebuilding.

@DNK89 quotes the conditions for a famine to be declared by the World Food Programme website: "crude death rates higher than two per 10,000 people per day, a global acute malnutrition rate greater than 30 percent, and an extreme lack of food affecting more than 20 percent of the population."
The already facing famine

Signs indicated at least some parts of the country were experiencing famine conditions in 2021. With many of the professional class having fled, I think it is likely this gets worse rather than better without outside assistance. I think odds are good Pakistan or a country that leans away from the US tries to build ties with the current regime (a wedge) and provides aid. Further, my rating is so low because I think the political conditions in the UN will make it unlikely an official famine is declared even if it is the case. In particular because I would anticipate the US blocking such a move to ensure the Taliban do not receive assistance or further legitimization
The UN rarely declares official famines anymore, instead concentrating on "people being at risk of famine".

The UN doesn't necessarily call a famine Just because a whole lot of people are real hungry. The criteria they use are, understandably, fairly fuzzy. As with almost everything almost all the time almost everywhere, political considerations influence this decision in unpredictable degrees. Stay tuned.
This seems to already to be the case, the only variable is UN recognition.

Information out of Afghanistan is hard to come by, but the declaration of a famine by the UN is a fairly rare event and the criteria are quite high. However, there is also a rapidly deteriorating situation in the country, so pegging the chance at a bit higher than base rate (around 16%)

There have been famines declared by the UN in 1984 (Ethiopia), 1991 (Somalia), 1996 (North Korea), 2000 (Ethiopia), 2008 (Sudan) and 2011 (Somalia) and 2017 (South Sudan) https://news.un.org/en/story/2011/07/382072-un-declares-famine-two-regions-southern-somalia https://news.un.org/en/story/2017/02/551812-famine-declared-region-south-sudan-un

A famine declaration requires evidence of crude death rates higher than two per 10,000 people per day, a global acute malnutrition rate greater than 30 percent, and an extreme lack of food affecting more than 20 percent of the population. Have not been able to form a strong opinion one way or the other. So this is my starting estimate. Will revisit this over time

Unfortunately world has accepted the current govermers. They do not know how to run a country. All influential powers want them to stay so UN will take a humanitarian position just for the sake that they can't do anything else. Truely there is famine in Afghanistan

January has been slightly drier than average in Kabul. The west of the country was already rated in crisis in mid 2021 following poor harvests. The economic situation is still very fragile and Afghanistan is not likely to find much aid from the major powers or Pakistan this year. Fuel and food commodity prices are very high currently.
